page.title: 02The Origins of Kinver
page.content: Earlier known as Kinfare, the village is recorded in the Domesday Book as Chenevare meaning Â£Great Ridge'. It belonged to the King as part of the Royal Forest. In the 12th century the king's tenant was Philip Holgate. In 1257 Kinver was given a charter granting the privilege of holding a market or fayre. This charter was renewed by several monarchs, the last being Charles 1 in 1629. This charter may be seen in Kinver Parish Church. An earlier charter is believed to exist dating from 736 and 964 A.D.. We are told that Ethelbald granted a piece of land to Earl Cynebert for the purpose of founding a Â£retreat'. Cynebert may have given the name Kynfer.
